questions.text: The normal Doppler waveform of the venous blood flow is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Monophasic

 

Explanation:

 

The normal Doppler waveform for venous blood flow is monophasic. This refers to the uniform, steady, and continuous flow pattern typically observed in veins, unlike the varying phases seen in arterial blood flow. Monophasic waveforms indicate a lack of cardiac modulation and resistance, which is characteristic of venous structures that carry blood under lower pressure and with less force than arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biphasic: Generally observed in visceral arteries, biphasic waveforms show two distinct directional phases in the blood flow, reflecting the resistance encountered by the blood as it moves through these arteries.

 

 

Option C. Triphasic: This waveform is characteristic of extremity arteries and includes three phases—forward flow, brief reverse flow, and forward flow again, which correspond to the cardiac cycle's effects on arterial blood movement.

 

 

Option D. Absent flow: This is not a normal finding and indicates a blockage or absence of blood flow, which requires further investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doppler waveforms refer to the morphology of pulsatile blood flow velocity tracings on spectral Doppler ultrasound. 

 

In Doppler ultrasound, the normal venous waveform is monophasic, indicating a steady flow without the complex fluctuations seen in arterial blood flow.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

Inhalational of anthrax spores (<5 microns) are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, carried to local mediastinal lymph nodes releasing toxins causing hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

It is category A bioterrorism agent along with plague, botulism

 

Treatment recommended with IV antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin+Clindamycin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical pneumonia occurs in Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Legionella pneumonia causing interstitial infiltrates

 

Option B. Lung abscess is seen as complication of infection with anaerobes, complication of pneumonia, atypical organisms like burkholderia, Infective endocarditis with septic embolism

 

Option D. Bronchopneumonia occurs due to pneumococcus, H.influenza etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the hallmark presentation of inhalational anthrax, indicating a severe systemic infection that requires immediate medical attention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Awareness of this presentation is crucial, particularly in contexts involving potential exposure to anthrax spores, such as bioterrorism.

questions.text: What of the following stain can be used for staining Iron in tissues? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prussian blue  

 

Perl's iron stain is the classic method for demonstrating iron in tissues. The section is treated with dilute hydrochloric acid to release ferric ions from binding proteins. These ions then react with potassium ferrocyanide to produce an insoluble blue compound (the Prussian blue reaction).

 

 

Used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, lead toxicity to visualize iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts and myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Masson's trichrome: This stain is used to differentiate between collagen and other tissue components. It stains collagen fibers blue or green, muscle fibers red, and cytoplasm light red or pink. It is not used for detecting iron.

 

Option C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): PAS stain is primarily used to detect glycogen and other polysaccharides in tissues. It stains these components magenta. PAS is not useful for detecting iron in tissues.

 

Option D. Fite-Faraco: This is a special stain used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium responsible for leprosy. It is not used for staining iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussian blue stain is specifically used for detecting iron deposits in tissues, particularly in cases of iron overload or iron-related disorders.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisome biogenesis disorder caused by defects in peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are essential organelles involved in various metabolic processes, and their dysfunction leads to Zellweger syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in mitochondria. Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in cells, and defects in mitochondria lead to different diseases, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lysosomes: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in lysosomes. Lysosomes are responsible for breaking down cellular waste and are associated with lysosomal storage disorders, which are different from peroxisomal disorders like Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Nucleus: Zellweger syndrome is not primarily caused by a defect in the nucleus. It is a peroxisomal disorder, and the genetic mutations associated with Zellweger syndrome typically affect genes related to peroxisome biogenesis, not nuclear genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Which of the following types of pain stimulus is associated with the Carrageenan-induced experimental pain model?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory stimulus

 

The Carrageenan-induced pain model, also called the Carrageenan-Induced Paw Edema model, is a well-known model of acute inflammation.

 

It is employed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory properties of a variety of synthetic and natural substances. A non-antigenic phlogistic polysaccharide derived from red seaweed, carrageenan is frequently added to processed foods as a thickening, stabilizing, gelling, and emulsifying agent. The activation of the complement system and inflammatory mediators is caused by the sulphated sugars found in carrageenan.

 

Mechanism:


Carrageenan is injected subcutaneously into the plantar surface of the rat paw to cause inflammation. This process results in temporary inflammation and acute swelling, which peaks 3 to 5 hours after injection and subsides in 24 hours.

 

Postcapillary venules dilate due to the action of carrageenan, causing inflammatory cells and fluid to exude. During this process, a number of pro-inflammatory mediators are released. The cyclooxygenase pathway's activation is commonly associated with the carrageenan model. A biphasic curve represents the edema caused by carrageenan.

 

  • Part of the initial phase of inflammation caused by carrageenan is attributed to injection trauma and the release of acute phase mediators, particularly bradykinin, histamine, and serotonin.
  • The second phase of carrageenan-induced inflammation, which happens about three hours after carrageenan is added, is mostly caused by prostaglandins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Carrageenan-induced pain model is a widely used experimental model to study acute inflammation, especially in assessing the efficacy of anti-inflammatory drugs. It characterizes the inflammatory response through the release of mediators like prostaglandins, histamine, and serotonin.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

 

The substantia nigra is the marked structure in the transverse section of the brain that is shown. Degeneration of the substantia nigra is observed in Parkinson's disease, commonly referred to as paralysis agitans.

 

Due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which aid in the manufacture of dopamine, the substantia nigra is pigmented. The substantia nigra lacks or has less pigmentation in Parkinson's disease.

 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors. It's also known as paralysis agitans due to the motor dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: Incorrect because depression is typically associated with dysfunctions in other brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, not specifically the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Alzheimer’s disease: Incorrect as Alzheimer's disease primarily involves the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, leading to amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, rather than specific damage to the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: Incorrect because Huntington’s disease involves degeneration of the striatum and other parts of the brain but does not primarily affect the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

Collagen III is the first to be synthesized in the early stages of wound healing and is replaced by collagen I, the dominant skin collagen. Initially there is random deposition of collagen during the granulation tissue formation which is further enhanced by enzyme-induced covalent cross-linking. This process matures the collagen into complex structures that are reoriented for tensile strength restoration. Collagen remodeling continues for months after wound closure and the tensile strength of the repaired tissue increases to about 80–85% of normal tissue if all processes proceed without any perturbations.

 

Note –

  • Collagen is a major structural protein found in connective tissue.

 

  • Type I is the most abundant form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type II:

  • Location: Found primarily in cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye.
  • Function: Provides structural support to cartilage and vitreous body.
  • Disease: Deficiency leads to severe chondrodysplasias and osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Type IV:

  • Location: Found in basement membranes.
  • Function: Provides structural integrity to the basement membrane.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Alport syndrome.

 

Option D. Type V:

  • Location: Found as a minor component in tissues containing collagen I.
  • Function: Contributes to the regulation of collagen fibril assembly.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type I (EDS-I).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Properties of Different types of Collagen:

questions.text: In SCID, what type of DNA repair is defective? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-homologous end joining repair

 

Human severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) is the most serious inherited immunological deficit which is caused due to defects in the predominant pathway for double-strand break repair called nonhomologous DNA end joining, or NHEJ.

 

Defects in DNA Repair:

 

 

Other Options: 

 

The table in the provided image highlights various DNA repair pathways and the associated cancer syndromes when these pathways are defective:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Base modifications, abasic sites
  • Cancer Syndromes: Not yet reported

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Intra-strand crosslinks, bulky adducts
  • Cancer Syndromes: Xeroderma pigmentosum, ERCC6L2 deficiency

 

Option C. Mismatch repair (MMR):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Mismatches, indels
  • Cancer Syndromes: Constitutional MMR syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by defects in the NHEJ pathway, which is responsible for repairing double-strand breaks in DNA. This defect impairs the immune system, leading to severe immunodeficiency.

 

Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
  • Cancer Syndromes: Ligase IV deficiency, XLF/NHEJ1 deficiency, Rothmund-Thompson syndrome, Werner syndrome

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection
Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of thyroid swelling. A fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) report suggests papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, and the nodule appears “cold” on scan. Which of the following would not be an appropriate treatment option for her? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

 

Radioiodine ablation (radioactive iodine therapy) is contraindicated in pregnant women due to the potential risk of fetal radiation exposure. Radioactive iodine can cross the placenta and cause severe fetal hypothyroidism or other developmental issues, making this treatment unsuitable during pregnancy. Alternative surgical approaches like total thyroidectomy or hemithyroidectomy can be considered based on the tumor size, lymph node involvement, and other clinical factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Thyroidectomy: This is a valid treatment option for managing papillary carcinoma in pregnant patients, especially if there is a concern about the aggressive nature of the tumor. Surgery is preferred during pregnancy over radiation-based therapies.

 

Option B. Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection: Lymph node involvement in papillary carcinoma often necessitates lymph node dissection along with thyroidectomy. This is another viable option during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Right Hemithyroidectomy: For small, localized tumors, hemithyroidectomy may be an appropriate option. Surgery during pregnancy can be safely performed, typically in the second trimester to minimize risks to both the mother and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioiodine ablation is contraindicated during pregnancy due to fetal radiation exposure, making surgical approaches the preferred treatment for thyroid cancers diagnosed in pregnant patients.

questions.text: What is the angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope called? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azimuth angle

 

In laparoscopic surgery:

 

  • Azimuth angle: Angle between working port and telescope (15-30 degrees)
  • Essential for ergonomic comfort during surgery
  • Prevents instrument clash with camera
  • Not possible to generate in single incision laparoscopic surgery
  • Inadequate angle leads to difficulty in surgery

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between instrument and abdominal wall
  • Refers to vertical orientation of instruments
  • Not related to telescope-port relationship

 

Option C. Working angle:

 

  • Not a standard term in laparoscopic ergonomics
  • No specific angle is defined by this term

 

Option D. Manipulation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between two working ports
  • Refers to the angle between the surgeon's right and left-hand instruments
  • Different from telescope-port relationship

 

Educational Objective:

 

The angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope is called the Azimuth angle, which should ideally be 15-30 degrees for optimal ergonomics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Belladona

 

The symptoms described, including dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, increased heart rate, and dilated pupils, are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. Belladonna, contains tropane alkaloids with anticholinergic effects. Features of belladonna are same as that of Datura, and both belong to Solanaceae family.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Heroin: It is an Opioid (CNS depressant) and have symptoms such as sedation, coma, decreased vitas (respiratory depression, low BP, low Heart rate, low temperature), and miosis. Whereas in the question there is high pulse rate, and dilated pupils.

 

Option B) Morphine: is also an Opioid, and will have similar features as that of heroin.

 

Option C) Malathion: is an organophosphate insecticide. It will have cholinergic symptoms, like Diarrhea, urination excessive, miosis, bradycardia, emesis, lachrymation, and salivation (Mnemonic DUMBELS). These are exactly opposite of those mentioned in question.

 

Educational Objective

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus Niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae
  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.
  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.
  • Sign and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms. So, Atropa belladonna will also have features same as that of Datura: Dry hot skin, Dilatated pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Decreased Body Secretions, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium
  • Treatment is Physostigmine
  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha (α) neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta (β) neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta (δ) neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: Match the following transporters with the molecule they carry. (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1c, 2d, 3a, 4b

 

Hemopexin transports free heme. Haptoglobin binds to and transports hemoglobin. Pre-albumin, also known as transthyretin, transports thyroxin and retinol binding protein. Albumin transports various hydrophobic substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and many drugs. The correct match is:

 

  1. Hemopexin - c. Heme
    Hemopexin specifically binds and transports free heme to prevent its oxidative damage.
  2. Haptoglobin - d. Hemoglobin
    Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, preventing loss of iron and kidney damage.
  3. Pre-albumin - a. Thyroxin
    Pre-albumin (transthyretin) transports thyroxin (T4) and retinol-binding protein.
  4. Albumin - b. Free fatty acid
    Albumin transports a wide range of substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and various drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match can be given as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 630-631

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests: (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Positive FAST

 

Explanation:

 

The ultrasound image shows an anechoic area (appearing dark on ultrasound), which is fluid between the liver and kidney. This finding is indicative of a hemoperitoneum, suggesting that the FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) scan is positive. A positive FAST scan in this context typically points to the presence of free fluid in the abdomen, which in trauma settings, is usually due to bleeding, confirming a hemoperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negative FAST: This would imply no visible free fluid; the image, however, shows clear evidence of fluid.

 

Option C. Equivocal FAST: This term would be used if the findings were unclear or uncertain, which is not the case here as the fluid is distinctly visible.

 

Option D. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the abdominal cavity and would present differently on an ultrasound, typically as increased echogenicity reflecting off the free air; this is not visible in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anechoic fluid between liver and kidney is suggestive of hemoperitoneum-FAST positive

 

eFAST: Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma

 

Focus:

 

  • Hemoperitoneum (free fluid in abdomen)
  • Pericardial effusion
  • Pneumothorax
  • Hemothorax

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 cm

 

Explanation:

 

  • The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is usually 6-7 cm. This measurement is essential in gynecological evaluations and procedures.
  • This measurement helps in assessing normal uterine anatomy and can be used in various clinical procedures such as the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Ovary: The ovary measures about 3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm.
  • Fallopian Tube: The length of the Fallopian tube is about 10 cm, and the lumen is 1-2 mm at the isthmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is 6-7 cm.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition Pg 25, Dutta's textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 7

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

 

Clinical history is suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Causative organism - Larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of T. solium.

 

Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of brain) is the most common and most serious form of cysticercosis. About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Other clinical features of neurocysticercosis are increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders, aphasia and visual disturbances. It is considered as the second most common cause of intracranial space occupying lesion (lCSOL) after tuberculosis in India.

 

Treatment –

 

  1. For cysticercosis, excision is the best method, wherever possible.
  2. Asymptomatic neurocysticercosis requires no treatment.
  3. For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis, praziquantel in a dose of 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20-30 days and albendazole in a dose of 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.
  4. Corticosteroids may be given along with praziquantel or albendazole to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.
  5. In addition, antiepileptic drugs should be given until the reaction of the brain has subsided.
  6. Operative intervention is indicated for hydrocephalus

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Antiparasitic drugs followed by steroids: The correct sequence is to give steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs.

 

Option C. Steroids before antiepileptics: While steroids are important, antiepileptics are also necessary to control seizures.

 

Option D. Continue antiepileptics: While antiepileptics are part of the treatment, steroids and antiparasitic drugs are also necessary for managing neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

questions.text: Vitamin C cannot be produced in humans due to lack of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-gulonolactone oxidase

 

Most animals and plants can synthesize ascorbic acid from glucose. Man, higher primates, guineapigs and bats are the only species which cannot synthesize ascorbic acid (block in gulonolactone oxidase step). They lack the genes responsible for the synthesis of this enzyme.

 

Details of L-gulonolactone Oxidase:

  • Role: This enzyme is responsible for converting L-gulonolactone to ascorbic acid (vitamin C).
  • Deficiency: Humans, higher primates, guinea pigs, and certain other species lack this enzyme due to mutations or absence of the gene encoding it, which blocks the synthesis of ascorbic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Xylitol reductase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of xylitol to xylulose but is not related to the synthesis of vitamin C.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This enzyme complex plays a critical role in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration but is not involved in vitamin C synthesis.

 

Option D. UDP glucose dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of UDP-glucuronic acid from UDP-glucose but has no role in vitamin C production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Humans cannot synthesize vitamin C due to the lack of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase, which is necessary for the final step in the biosynthetic pathway of ascorbic acid from glucose.

choices.text: Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

questions.text: Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can effectively prevent which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Graft versus host disease

 

Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can effectively prevent transfusion-associated Graft-Versus-Host Disease (TA-GVHD). TA-GVHD is a rare but serious complication that can occur when viable T lymphocytes present in the transfused blood product proliferate and attack the recipient's tissues. This is particularly dangerous in immunocompromised individuals or those receiving blood from close relatives where the donor lymphocytes are not recognized as foreign by the recipient's immune system.

 

Irradiation of blood products helps to inactivate T lymphocytes, thereby preventing their proliferation and reducing the risk of TA-GVHD. This is crucial in certain patient populations, such as those undergoing bone marrow transplantation, those with congenital immunodeficiency disorders, and patients receiving blood from relatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HLA alloimmunization: HLA alloimmunization refers to the development of antibodies against human leukocyte antigens (HLA) due to exposure to foreign antigens through transfusions or pregnancy. It is not specifically prevented by irradiating blood products.

 

Option C. Immunomodulation: Immunomodulation refers to the modulation of the immune response by transfused blood products, which is not specifically targeted by irradiation.

 

Option D. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare but severe reaction that causes acute respiratory distress following transfusion. It is primarily caused by antibodies in the transfused blood reacting with the recipient's leukocytes, not by the presence of viable T lymphocytes, so irradiation does not prevent TRALI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of irradiated RBCs is specifically recommended to prevent Graft-Versus-Host Disease (GVHD), making it the correct answer for this scenario.

questions.text: Most potent biological Estrogen: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estradiol

 

Explanation:

 

Estrogens are a group of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the different forms of estrogen, estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the dominant form of estrogen during the reproductive years.

 

Estradiol binds with the highest affinity to estrogen receptors compared to other forms like estrone and estriol, which is why it exerts the most potent biological effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is less potent than estradiol and is the primary form of estrogen after menopause. It has a weaker affinity for estrogen receptors and thus, exerts less biological activity.

 

Option C. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three primary estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy and has the least biological activity due to its low affinity for estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are a mixture of several types of estrogens, typically used in hormone replacement therapy. They are not as biologically potent as estradiol when considered individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent biological estrogen.

questions.text:
Match the following plant poisons with their active principles. (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

Column:1

1. Datura

2. Opium

3. Abrus precatorius

4. Nux vomica

 

Column:2

a. Atropine
b. Abrin
c. Thebaine
d. Strychnine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d.

 

The correct match is 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d.

 

The active ingredients of Datura include the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. The seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked.

 

Manifestations of Datura toxicity:

 

  • Dry hot skin (Temperature rises up to 42°C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
  • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation.
  • Diplopia.
  • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels.
  • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking).
  • Drunken gait.
  • Delirium.
  • Drowsiness.
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure.

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and includes natural opioids like morphine, codeine, and thebaine.

 

Abrin is a toxalbumin of the plant Abrus precatorius, and it acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

 

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

 

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen).
  • Abrine (an amino acid).
  • Abralin (a glucoside).

 

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, leading to cell death. Clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, and miosis. Faintness, dyspnea, and convulsions may also occur.

 

The poison obtained from Strychnos nux-vomica seeds is strychnine. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that acts at the postsynaptic membranes of ventral horn motor neurons. Hence, the blockade of these receptors results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features:

 

  • Tonic-clonic seizures.
  • Opisthotonus (body arched in hypertension).
  • Risus sardonicus.

choices.text: Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed
Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic
Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.text: An epileptic patient on levetiracetam has been seizure-free for 2 years. But he develops agitation and anger issues interfering with his day-to-day activities as a result of the drug intake. Which of the following measures is to be taken next? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months

 

Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic drug that binds to SV2A on the vesicles and modulates the release of Neurotransmitters. It can cause anger, agitation and mood disturbances as a side effect. In such cases, the drug should be gradually tapered over the next 6 months, but not abruptly stopped as that might lead to rebound seizures.

 

Rationale for Tapering:

 

  • Side Effects: The patient is experiencing significant side effects (agitation and anger) that are interfering with daily activities.
  • Seizure-Free Period: While the patient has been seizure-free for 2 years, abruptly stopping the medication could lead to rebound seizures.
  • Gradual Tapering: Tapering the medication slowly over the next 6 months is a safer approach. It allows the patient's body to adjust and reduces the risk of withdrawal seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure-free interval is needed: While a longer seizure-free interval might be ideal, continuing the medication despite significant side effects is not practical. The patient’s quality of life is important, and the side effects need to be addressed.

 

Option C. Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic: Abruptly stopping levetiracetam is not recommended due to the risk of withdrawal seizures. Switching to a different antiepileptic drug (AED) should be done cautiously, and often a cross-tapering strategy is used.

 

Option D. Discontinue the drug as he is seizure-free: Discontinuing the drug abruptly is not advisable, even if the patient has been seizure-free, because it could trigger rebound seizures. A gradual tapering is always preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient on levetiracetam experiences significant psychiatric side effects, the best approach is to slowly taper the medication over several months to prevent rebound seizures and address the side effects.

questions.text: What is the origin of the fibers marked by the arrow? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above image is the cross-section of the human brain in which the marked arrow indicates the fornix.
  • Fornix belongs to projectional fibers which are the type of white matter fibers. Fornix forms the efferent fibers of the hippocampus and connects it with the mammillary body. Hence the origin of fibers is hippocampus
  • The fornix is a white matter bundle located in the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres which arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.
  • It connects various nodes of a limbic circuitry and is believed to play a key role in cognition and episodic memory recall.
  • Fornix is an example of association fiber and is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • The hippocampus is a seahorse-shaped structure located within the temporal lobes of the brain. The fornix originates from the hippocampus. Specifically, it receives input from the hippocampus and sends axons that project back to the hippocampus. This loop of connections is involved in memory formation and retrieval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Habenular: The habenular nuclei are small structures located near the thalamus and are involved in various functions, including the regulation of the pineal gland's activity. The fornix is not directly associated with the habenular nuclei. Instead, it primarily connects the hippocampus to other structures in the limbic system.

 

Option C. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain. The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies. This connection is an essential component of the Papez circuit, a neural circuit involved in memory and emotion.

 

Option D. Amygdala: The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes and plays a key role in processing emotions, particularly fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala is part of the limbic system, it is not directly connected to the fornix. Instead, the amygdala communicates with other limbic structures through various neural pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

 

The clinical features described are suggestive of McArdle's disease (glycogen storage disease type V), which is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose in the muscle cells, resulting in exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle-debranching enzyme:

  • Deficiency: Causes Cori's disease (glycogen storage disease type III).
  • Clinical Features: Highly branched dextrin accumulates in liver and muscle, leading to fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and myopathy.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in the debranching process of glycogenolysis, but the primary symptoms are different from those described in the question.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • Deficiency: Causes Tarui's disease (glycogen storage disease type VII).
  • Clinical Features: Exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and myoglobinuria, similar to McArdle's, but also includes hemolytic anemia due to the enzyme's role in glycolysis in red blood cells.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not directly in glycogen metabolism.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Deficiency: Causes Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type Ia).
  • Clinical Features: Fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
  • Note: This enzyme deficiency affects the liver's ability to release glucose, but not directly linked to muscle symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following clinical examination was performed. What lesion would cause an exaggerated reflex? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper motor neuron

 

The clinical examination shown in the image involves testing the ankle jerk reflex, which is a deep tendon reflex. Exaggerated or hyperactive reflexes are typically a sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. UMN lesions occur in the neural pathways above the level of the anterior horn cell in the spinal cord, which includes the brain and the spinal cord itself. When these pathways are damaged, there is a loss of inhibitory control over the lower motor neurons, leading to hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes).

 

Upper motor neuron lesions are characterized by:

 

  • Hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes)
  • Spasticity
  • Positive Babinski sign
  • Weakness without significant muscle atrophy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyneuropathy: This condition affects multiple peripheral nerves and is typically associated with diminished or absent reflexes rather than exaggerated reflexes.

 

Option B. Radiculopathy: Damage to the nerve roots also results in lower motor neuron signs, including reduced reflexes and weakness in the distribution of the affected nerve root.

 

Option D. Lower motor neuron: Lesions here cause diminished or absent reflexes due to direct damage to the anterior horn cells or peripheral nerves that innervate muscles.

 

Educational Objective:


Exaggerated reflexes, such as an exaggerated ankle jerk reflex, are indicative of an upper motor neuron lesion. Lower motor neuron lesions, including those caused by polyneuropathy and radiculopathy, typically result in diminished or absent reflexes.

choices.text: Inhibits HMG Co reductase
Activates PPAR alpha
Binds to deoxycholic acid
Inhibit intestinal absorption of cholesterol

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for hyperlipidemia develops gallstones. What is the mechanism of action of the causative drug that was given to this patient? ((INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Activates PPAR alpha

 

Fibrates, such as clofibrate, fenofibrate, and gemfibrozil, are used to treat hyperlipidemia. These drugs work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα). The activation of PPARα leads to:

 

  1. Increased synthesis of lipoprotein lipase, which accelerates the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins.
  2. Reduced production of VLDL and chylomicrons.
  3. Lower levels of triglycerides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins inhibit HMG CoA reductase. These drugs are used as lipid-lowering agents in dyslipidemia and are associated with statin-induced myopathy. These drugs do not lead to development of gallstones.

 

Option C. Bile Acid Sequestrants bind to deoxycholic acid and prevent its reabsorption in the intestine. It may result in deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe is a drug that acts by inhibiting intestinal absorption of cholesterol

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrates are lipid-lowering agents that work by activating PPARα. While effective at reducing triglycerides and VLDL, they can increase the risk of gallstone formation due to increased cholesterol content in bile. This is an important consideration when choosing lipid-lowering therapy, especially in patients at risk for cholelithiasis.

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:

 

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.

 

Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 491-492,479,

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck Stabilization
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X ray
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support
The doctor should order a cervical X ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident presented with paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization

 

The given clinical situation is suggestive of a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

 

This option is correct because the patient is experiencing paralysis of both upper and lower limbs, which is indicative of a potential cervical spine injury. In such cases, it is crucial not to move the patient until the cervical spine is stabilized to prevent any further damage. Using a portable X-ray machine can help assess the cervical spine without the need to move the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X-rays: The patient's cervical spine must be stabilized before any radiographic evaluation is performed.

 

Option C. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X-ray AP and lateral views without any cervical support: This option is not advisable because taking X-rays without cervical support can potentially worsen the patient's condition if there is a cervical spine injury. The patient's neck should be stabilized before any imaging is done.

 

Option D. The doctor should order a cervical X-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself: This option is not recommended because moving the patient without proper cervical spine stabilization can lead to further injury. The priority should be to immobilize the cervical spine and use imaging techniques that do not require moving the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management in a trauma patient with suspected cervical fracture consists of:

 

  1. The immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases is spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board
  2. It is followed by eliciting extremity movement to grossly assess spinal cord function. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicated an associated fracture.

 

Imaging is done by X-ray or CT with portable X-ray machines being preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but they cannot be used to visualize the cervicothoracic junction.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

questions.text: In males, urethritis is caused by all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gardnerella

 

Male urethritis can be classified into:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis: Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis: Caused by: 
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Mycoplasma hominis
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Gardnerella vaginalis is not associated with male urethritis. It is instead associated with bacterial vaginosis in females, causing a characteristic homogeneous white adherent discharge with fishy odor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neisseria: N. gonorrhoeae is a major cause of urethritis in males, presenting with purulent urethral discharge 2-5 days after exposure.

 

Option B. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma hominis is a recognized cause of non-gonococcal urethritis in males.

 

Option C. Trichomonas: T. vaginalis can cause non-gonococcal urethritis in males in addition to vaginal discharge in females.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardnerella vaginalis is not a causative organism of male urethritis, while recognizing the common bacterial and protozoal causes of both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis in males.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: What is the skin manifestation seen resulting from drugs used to treat amebic dysentery? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

 

  • Among the various medication available, metronidazole is drug used to treat amebic dysentery most frequently & it is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE), which is a drug-induced skin manifestation.
  • Metronidazole can cause maculopapular rashes, but it also has a higher likelihood of causing a fixed drug eruption.
  • Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They can cause a burning sensation and appear on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa.
  • They frequently appear alone or in small groups and return to the same spot. On re-exposure to the harmful drug, however, new lesions may develop on various body parts. FDE is a form of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Some of the most frequently prescribed medications that cause FDE are NSAIDs Tetracyclines and paracetamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urticaria

 

  • While urticaria (hives) can be a common reaction to many drugs, it is not specifically associated with the treatment of amoebic dysentery.
  • Urticaria is characterized by raised, often itchy, red or skin-colored wheals on the surface of the skin as shown below.

 

 

  • It is usually as an immediate hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Option C. Maculopapular rash

 

  • A maculopapular rash is a skin change that can occur with many conditions or as a reaction to various drugs.
  • It is characterized by a flat, red area on the skin that is covered with small confluent bumps as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • While this type of rash can be seen with many types of medications, it is not the most characteristic skin manifestation resulting from drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, inflamed skin.
  • It is not a drug-induced condition but rather a type of eczema that has a strong genetic predisposition and is commonly associated with allergic diseases.
  • It is not typically associated with amoebic dysentery treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole).
  • While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cladosporium

 

  • The dematiaceous (brown-pigment) fungi are a large and heterogenous group of molds that cause a wide range of diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.
  • Among the more important human pathogens are Alternaria species, Bipolaris species, Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) bantiana, Curvularia species, Exophiala species, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Madurella species, Phialophora species, Scedosporium prolificans, Scytalidium dimidiatum, and Wangiella dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor species: Incorrect Mucor species are not dematiaceous fungi. They are non-pigmented (hyaline) fungi that cause mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
 

Option B. Aspergillus niger: Incorrect Aspergillus niger is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a black mold, but it does not belong to the group of dematiaceous fungi. It is a common cause of aspergillosis.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cladosporium is a dematiaceous fungus, characterized by its dark pigmentation due to melanin in its cell walls, and it is associated with various diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. She has irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopic beats. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium Carbonate

 

Barium carbonate poisoning is characterized by severe hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which leads to symptoms such as muscle paralysis and irregular pulse. The ECG changes, such as multiple ventricular ectopic beats, are also indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminum Phosphide: This poison releases phosphine gas in the stomach, which inhibits cytochrome C oxidase and causes oxidative stress, leading to cytotoxic effects. The main symptom is profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Zinc Phosphide: Similar to aluminum phosphide, zinc phosphide also releases phosphine gas and causes oxidative stress and cytochrome C oxidase inhibition, leading to cytotoxic effects and profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that causes bleeding and bruising with an elevated PT/INR, but it does not cause hypokalemia or the associated symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia with symptoms such as muscle paralysis, irregular pulse, and ECG changes like ventricular ectopic beats strongly suggest poisoning with barium carbonate.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically seen in diabetic retinopathy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tractional retinal detachment

 

Explanation:


Tractional retinal detachment (TRD) is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). In PDR, new vessels proliferate and are accompanied by fibrous tissue formation. When this fibrous tissue contracts, it pulls on the retina, leading to tractional retinal detachment. This typically occurs as a late complication of PDR, following vitreous hemorrhage and fibrovascular proliferation.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Myopic refractive error: This is incorrect. Myopic refractive error is not associated with diabetic retinopathy. It is a refractive condition where light focuses in front of the retina rather than on it.

 

Option C. Posterior staphyloma: This is incorrect. Posterior staphyloma is typically associated with high myopia, not diabetic retinopathy. It represents an outward bulging of the posterior pole of the eye.

 

Option D. Retinoschisis: This is incorrect. Retinoschisis, which is a splitting of the retinal layers, is not a characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy. It is commonly seen in degenerative conditions and as a congenital condition.

 

Educational Objective: 


Tractional retinal detachment is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, caused by the contraction of fibrovascular tissue that develops with neovascularization.

questions.text: A young girl presents with menstrual irregularity, acne, increased hair growth with a Ferriman Gallway score of 6, and a BMI of 29. Her mother has diabetes. Which is not a management option?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCP + Anti androgen

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used alone for managing symptoms like acne and menstrual irregularity in PCOS. The addition of anti-androgens is typically reserved for cases where OCPs alone do not manage hirsutism effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCP: OCPs are a standard treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism.

 

Option C. Yoga + Exercise: Yoga and exercise are recommended for weight management and improving insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Counsel for metabolic syndrome: Counseling for metabolic syndrome is crucial given her high BMI and family history of diabetes.

 

Educational objective:

 

In managing PCOS-like symptoms, initial treatment often starts with OCPs. Additional treatments like anti-androgens are considered if initial treatments are insufficient. Lifestyle modifications are always beneficial.

questions.text: Treatment of open fracture of femur: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open reduction and external fixation 

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin. 
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound. 
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson Classification:

 

 

  • All open fractures are emergencies.
  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound. 
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis. 
  • They are frequently associated with injuries to surrounding vessels and nerves, which must be addressed as well. 
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used. 
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection. 
  • Immediately debride the wound of contaminated and devitalized tissue, copiously irrigate, and repeat debridement within 24-72 hours (Delayed wound closure is preferable).
  • Type and method of fixation:

 

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin –Ilizarov fixator.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Closed reduction and internal fixation: Closed reduction is not done for an open fracture. An open fracture inherently involves a break in the skin and contamination. It requires surgical exploration, debridement, and irrigation of the wound in the operating room. Attempting a closed reduction would significantly increase the risk of deep infection (osteomyelitis). Internal fixation (e.g., with an intramedullary nail) can be used for less severe open fractures (Gustilo-Anderson Type I, II, and sometimes IIIA), after thorough open debridement. However, the combination with closed reduction makes this option incorrect for an open fracture.

 

Option D. Closed reduction and external fixation: Closed reduction is incorrect for an open fracture due to the necessity of open wound management. External fixation is a valid and often preferred method of stabilization for open fractures, particularly severe ones or as a temporary measure. However, the initial phase must involve open management of the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The open fractures are best treated with open reduction and external fixation with the use of external fixators like ilizarov fixator.

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%.
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.
ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%.
AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases.

questions.text: All are true regarding heart failure except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.

 

Non-cardiovascular death refers to mortality due to causes other than cardiovascular diseases, such as infections, accidents, or malignancies.

 

The majority of deaths in HFrEF (Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction) are due to cardiovascular causes (85%), and only 15% are due to non-cardiovascular causes.

 

In contrast, in HFpEF (Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction), 60% of deaths are cardiovascular, and 40% are non-cardiovascular.

 

Therefore, non-cardiovascular death is actually more prevalent in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients, making option B incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%: This statement is correct. Both HFpEF and HFrEF patients have similar 5-year mortality rates, approximately 50%. This indicates that having a preserved ejection fraction does not necessarily correlate with a better long-term survival rate compared to reduced ejection fraction.

 

Option C. ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%: This statement is correct. Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are known to cause a persistent cough in about 15% of patients and angioedema, a more serious but less common side effect, in approximately 1% of patients.

 

Option D. AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases: This statement is correct. Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is indeed common among elderly patients and is a significant cause of cardioembolic strokes, accounting for about 25% of such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-cardiovascular deaths are more common in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients.

questions.text: Apart from the abdomen, which body part is included in e-FAST? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic cavity

 

eFAST or extended FAST covers 4 regions of abdomen (epigastrium, right and left paracolic areas and pelvis) and both the thoracic spaces.

 

Correct. The e-FAST exam extends the basic FAST exam by including views of the thoracic cavity, specifically looking for evidence of pneumothorax or hemothorax. This is done by assessing the pleural spaces on both sides of the chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retroperitoneum: These injuries are often missed on e-FAST.

 

Option B. Peripheral vessels: Peripheral vessels are not the primary focus of the e-FAST exam. The main goal of e-FAST is to rapidly identify free fluid in specific body cavities that might indicate trauma.

 

Option D. Dural and subdural spaces: These spaces are within the cranial cavity and pertain to the brain. They are not part of the e-FAST exam.

 

In summary, the e-FAST exam primarily evaluates the abdomen for evidence of trauma, but it also extends to the thoracic cavity to look for signs of pneumothorax or hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma, which is a bedside ultrasound examination used to evaluate trauma patients. It involves the use of a portable ultrasound machine to assess for free fluid in the abdomen, chest, and around the heart.

 

 

In addition to identifying free fluid, e-FAST can also be used to evaluate for other injuries, such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pericardial effusion. E-FAST has become a standard of care in trauma evaluation and is a valuable tool in the early detection and treatment of life-threatening injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

choices.text: Strength of muscle contraction
Intensity of stimulus
Amplitude of action potential
Duration of stimulus

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensity of stimulus

 

The Weber-Fechner law is a psychophysical law that describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the resulting sensation.

 

According to this law, the perceived magnitude of a sensory stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity. In other words, as the intensity of the stimulus increases, the change needed to produce a noticeable difference in sensation also increases, and this relationship is logarithmic rather than linear.

 

The law was first formulated by the German scientists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner in the mid-19th century and has since been applied to a wide range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, and touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of muscle contraction: This is unrelated to the Weber-Fechner law, which does not concern muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Amplitude of action potential: While action potentials are critical for neural transmission, the Weber-Fechner law specifically relates to the perception of stimulus intensity, not the electrical properties of neurons.

 

Option D. Duration of stimulus: The duration of a stimulus affects perception in different ways but is not the focus of the Weber-Fechner law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Weber-Fechner law illustrates the logarithmic relationship between the actual intensity of a stimulus and the perceived intensity, emphasizing that the human sensory system scales the perception of stimulus magnitude logarithmically rather than linearly.

 

Additional information Other Laws in Physiology:

 

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies states that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important.
  • Law of projection - Regardless of stimulation point for a particular sensory pathway (along its course to cortex), conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of receptor.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Gierke's disease

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Von Gierke’s disease (type I)

 

Salient features of Von Gierke’s Disease –

 

  • It is the most common type of glycogen storage disease.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is deficient.
  • Fasting hypoglycemia that does not respond to stimulation by adrenaline. The glucose cannot be released from liver during overnight fasting .
  • Clinical Features: Hyperlipidemia, lactic acidosis and ketosis.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate is accumulated, so it is channeled to HMP shunt pathway producing more ribose and more purine nucleotides.
  • Purines are then catabolized to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia
  • Glycogen gets deposited in liver. Massive liver enlargement may lead to cirrhosis.
  • Children usually die in early childhood.
  • Renomegaly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pompe's disease: This is a glycogen storage disease characterized by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase. It primarily affects muscles and causes cardiomegaly but does not present with the same biochemical profile as Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option C. McArdle's disease: This is characterized by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase and primarily affects muscle metabolism, leading to muscle cramps and myoglobinuria after exercise, but not the described biochemical abnormalities or hepatomegaly.

 

Option D. Cori's disease: Also known as Forbes disease or glycogen storage disease type III, it is caused by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme. While it can cause hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, it does not present with the specific profile of ketonemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperlipidemia seen in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual.
The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects.
The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.
The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients.

questions.text: Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50). Both LD50 and ED50 are calculated by checking different doses in a population.

 

  • It represents the margin of safety of a drug. A higher Clinical Therapeutic Index indicates that a drug has a greater margin of safety, and can be given at higher doses without causing significant adverse effects.
  • The Clinical Therapeutic Index is an important consideration in the development and use of new medications, and helps healthcare providers determine the appropriate dose for individual patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual: This description is incorrect because the therapeutic index is determined based on population data, not individual data.

 

Option B. The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects: This describes the therapeutic window or therapeutic range, not the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients: This is a general description of an effective and safe dosage regimen but does not specifically describe the therapeutic index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50) in a population, representing the drug's margin of safety. A higher Therapeutic Index indicates a greater margin of safety.

questions.text: Identify the following lines: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blaschko lines

 

Blaschko lines, also known as Blaschko's lines, are an intricate and unique pattern of skin markings that follow a specific distribution on the human body. They are not visible under normal circumstances and only become apparent when certain skin conditions or genetic disorders manifest.
