They are thought to represent the migration and proliferation of embryonic cells during early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinderer’s lines - Two intersecting lines, one from the ala to the tragus and one from the lateral canthus.

 

 

Option B. Marionette lines are wrinkles at the corners of mouth

 

 

Option C. Relaxed skin tension lines refer to furrows that are created when the skin is pinched and relaxed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blaschko lines offer a fascinating insight into human embryonic development and their pattern can help diagnose several dermatological conditions. Each of these lines has specific implications in medical practice, particularly in dermatology, plastic surgery, and cosmetic procedures, illustrating the intersection of clinical knowledge with aesthetic considerations.

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. Муоріа
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: An intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done thereafter? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never replaced

 

In the case of a successful and uneventful intraocular lens (IOL) implantation during cataract surgery, there is typically no need to replace the IOL. These lenses are designed to be permanent solutions that do not require routine replacement. Modern IOLs are made from durable materials that are meant to last a lifetime without degrading or causing adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no routine schedule for replacing IOLs as they are designed to last a lifetime.

 

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract (or posterior capsule opacification) can often be treated with a simple laser procedure called a posterior capsulotomy, not by replacing the IOL.

 

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is related to the lens of the eye and loss of its elasticity, affecting near vision; IOLs implanted during cataract surgery do not correct presbyopia inherent to aging, but specific types of IOLs can be chosen to address presbyopia at the time of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

 

  • Incorrect IOL placed-Incorrect power or Incorrect Type
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

choices.text: Downregulation of CYP2C19
Downregulation of CYP2D6
Upregulation of CYP1A1
Downregulation of CYP2E1

questions.text: A patient of 45 year with history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel, However, she had another attack of stroke after 6 months. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the failure of clopidogrel in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Downregulation of CYP2C19


Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug used to prevent MI and stroke. The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient can be influenced by various factors, including genetic variations that affect drug metabolism.

 

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19. Genetic polymorphisms or downregulation of CYP2C19 can lead to reduced conversion of clopidogrel to its active form. This results in decreased antiplatelet activity and a higher risk of thrombotic events, such as stroke. Individuals with reduced function alleles of CYP2C19 are known as "poor metabolizers," and in these patients, clopidogrel may be less effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Downregulation of CYP2D6: While CYP2D6 is important for the metabolism of many drugs, it is not primarily responsible for the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2D6 would not significantly impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Option C. Upregulation of CYP1A1: CYP1A1 is not involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel. Its upregulation would not affect the activation of clopidogrel or its therapeutic efficacy.

 

Option D. Downregulation of CYP2E1: CYP2E1 is involved in the metabolism of ethanol and certain other drugs but does not play a significant role in the activation of clopidogrel. Therefore, downregulation of CYP2E1 would not impact clopidogrel's effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The failure of clopidogrel in preventing a second stroke in a patient may be due to the downregulation of CYP2C19. This enzyme is crucial for converting clopidogrel into its active form, and its reduced activity can lead to decreased antiplatelet effects and increased risk of thrombotic events.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown by arrow in the image?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isoniazid

 

Isoniazid is activated by Catalase Peroxidase and it acts by blocking the mycolic acid synthesis. It is a bactericidal drug that is effective against both intracellular and extracellular bacteria that are actively replicating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: It is the most bactericidal drug, that is effective against intra as well as extracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking RNA polymerase.


Option C. Pyrazinamide: It is also bactericidal, that is effective mainly against intracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking fatty acid synthase.


Option D. Ethambutol: It is a bacteriostatic 1st line anti-tubercular drug that acts against both intra and extracellular bacteria by blocking arabinosyl transferase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the mycobacterial cell wall, making it an effective first-line treatment for tuberculosis. The other first-line drugs have different mechanisms of action, such as inhibiting RNA polymerase (rifampicin), blocking fatty acid synthase (pyrazinamide), and inhibiting arabinosyl transferase (ethambutol).

choices.text: Endodermal sinus tumor
Malignant teratoma
Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysgerminoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass with raised LDH points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas usually arise in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. They currently account for approximately one-third of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors and are the most common malignant ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor: This is typically associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), not LDH.

 

Option C. Malignant teratoma: This type of tumor does not typically present with elevated LDH as the sole abnormal marker.

 

Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: This epithelial ovarian tumor is usually associated with elevated CA-125, not LDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminoma is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with an ovarian mass and elevated LDH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: AFP surveillance is done until 5 years of age.
At least one case of non-polio AFP should be detected annually per 100,000 population.
Stool specimen should reach the laboratory within 72 hours.
At least 80% should have follow-up after 60 days.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is False regarding AFP surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AFP surveillance is done until 5 years of age.

 

Option A: False. AFP (Acute Flaccid Paralysis) surveillance is conducted for children under 15 years of age, not until 5 years. The aim is to monitor for cases that could be indicative of poliovirus, especially in children under 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: True. The surveillance system should be able to detect at least one case of non-polio AFP annually per 100,000 children under 15 years of age. This ensures that the system is sensitive enough to detect potential cases, even in the absence of polio.

 

Option C: True. Stool samples collected from children with AFP must be sent to the laboratory within 72 hours to ensure the accuracy of poliovirus testing. The samples must be stored at 4-8°C to maintain the virus's integrity for analysis.

 

Option D: True. At least 80% of AFP cases should have a follow-up after 60 days to assess for residual paralysis. This follow-up is crucial to evaluate the long-term effects of paralysis and to ensure comprehensive surveillance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AFP surveillance is essential for monitoring poliovirus circulation and includes reporting cases in children under 15, timely stool sample analysis, and thorough follow-up for residual paralysis.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - Lamina propria 

 

Is an incorrect match because the structure labelled 4 shows the basement membrane rather than the lamina propria.

 

The image shows irregular cells attached to the basement membrane and is of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked as 4 in the image). It appears to have multiple layers. There is, however, only one layer of cells. The multi-layered appearance is caused by the nuclei of epithelial cells (shown as 3 in the image) being located at different levels.1`

 

The epithelium shows hair-like projections called cilia (marked as 1 in the image) and goblet cells (marked as 2 in the image). Goblet cells secrete mucous which helps to trap dust entering the passages. The cilia are capable of movement and help in the clearance of mucous

 

Example include epithelium lining the trachea and in large bronchi.

 

Other Options:

 

1- Cilia: These are the hair-like projections visible at the top of the epithelial cells, which help in moving mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory passages.

 

2- Goblet cells: These cells are interspersed between the epithelial cells and are responsible for producing mucus. They appear as clear, expanded cells at the level marked "2."

 

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell: The nuclei shown here are located at different heights within the cells, giving the epithelium a pseudostratified appearance.

 

4- Basement membrane: This layer supports the epithelium and is incorrectly labeled as the lamina propria in the options. It is a thin, fibrous structure evident just below the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure in the image are

 

1- Cilia

2- Goblet cell

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell

4- Basement membrane

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed

 

This is the classic test for immediate memory. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of digits (usually ranging from 5 to 9 numbers), and it tests the capacity of one's immediate memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps: This tests concentration.

 

Option C. Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed: This is more challenging than the forward span and is used to assess working memory.

 

Option D. Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps: Like the serial (100-7) test, it's more of an assessment for concentration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The digit span forward test, which involves repeating a sequence of numbers, is a measure of immediate memory and is a fundamental aspect of cognitive assessments.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 13.

questions.text: The structure passing through the central tendon of the diaphragm is: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. The IVC passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening, which is situated to the right of the central tendon. This opening allows the IVC to move between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophagus: The esophagus passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the esophageal hiatus, which is located just to the left of the central tendon. This allows the esophagus to traverse from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option B. Aorta: The descending (thoracic) aorta carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body. It passes through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus, which is posterior to the central tendon. The aorta then continues its descent into the abdominal cavity.

 

Option D. Sympathetic Chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, consists of a series of ganglia connected by nerve fibers. It runs vertically along each side of the vertebral column and is not directly associated with the diaphragm or its central tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diaphragm has three anatomic openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), the esophageal hiatus (T10), and the caval foramen (T8)

 

  • The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen.
  • Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus.
  • Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.

 

Sympathetic chain passes through the minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks. What is the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG to see cervical length

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has several risk factors for preterm labor, including a history of previous preterm births and cervical conization. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound (USG) to measure the cervical length at 11-14 weeks of gestation.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cervical length measurement: If the cervix is found to be short (less than 2.5 cm), with or without funneling of the internal os, cervical cerclage may be indicated.
  • Progesterone supplementation: If the cervical length is normal, the patient should be started on progesterone and serial cervical length measurements should be continued.
  • Cervical cerclage: This is a procedure where a suture is placed around the cervix to prevent or delay preterm birth. It can be done via the vaginal route using techniques like McDonald’s or Shirodkar's.
  • Abdominal cerclage: This is considered for patients with a prior failed vaginal cerclage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical Cerclage: While cerclage may be necessary, it should be based on the findings of cervical length measurement. Immediate cerclage without assessment is not recommended.

 

Option C. Complete Bed rest: Bed rest alone is not an effective strategy for preventing preterm labor and is not indicated without further assessment.

 

Option D. Abdominal cerclage: This is reserved for patients with a history of failed vaginal cerclage and is not the first-line approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with risk factors for preterm labor, including a history of cervical conization and previous preterm births, the next step is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound to measure cervical length at 11-14 weeks of gestation. Based on the findings, appropriate interventions, such as cervical cerclage or progesterone supplementation, can be considered.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg2094

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babesia

 

Babesia is not an intracellular parasite of hepatocytes. It is an intra-erythrocytic parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasma gondii can infect hepatocytes as part of its lifecycle.

 

Option B. Plasmodium: The liver stage (hepatic schizogony) of Plasmodium involves hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Leishmania species infect macrophages, which can reside in the liver, leading to intracellular infection in hepatocytes indirectly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obligate intracellular parasites-

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Leishmania spp.
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp. -> RBC
  • Toxoplasma gondii
  • Microsporidia

choices.text: Strength of correlation is same in A and B
Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B
Strength of the variation is more in B than A
Variation in variables is more with A than B

questions.text: A perinatologist is analyzing scatterplots from two research studies on the relationship between bone marrow density and gestational age. Study A shows data points tightly clustered along a trend line, while Study B shows data points that are more spread out but still follow a general trend line. Which statement correctly describes the relationship between bone marrow density and gestational age based on these observations? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B

 

  • Graph A represents stronger correlation than graph B.
  • More compact and close the dots are to the line, stronger is the relation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following organelles is absent in the area of the cardiac muscle marked:  
(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosome

 

Lysosomes are not typically concentrated in the marked perinuclear area of cardiac muscle cells. Instead, lysosomes are distributed throughout the cytoplasm of the cell. This means that they are present in the cell but do not show a significant concentration or structure in the indicated area of cardiac muscle fibers.

 

In cardiac muscle cells, mitochondria are abundant due to the high-energy demand for contraction, and endoplasmic reticulum (sarcoplasmic reticulum) and Golgi bodies are usually present in the perinuclear area for synthesis and modification of proteins and other important molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are highly abundant in cardiac muscle cells, particularly near areas that need significant energy. The heart has a high demand for ATP due to its continuous contractions, and mitochondria are essential for this energy supply.

 

Option C. Golgi bodies: Golgi bodies are present in cardiac muscle cells, often localized around the perinuclear area. They are important for modifying, packaging, and sorting proteins, which are needed in various cellular functions, including those in muscle contraction and maintenance.

 

Option D. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER): The endoplasmic reticulum (or sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells) is crucial for calcium storage and release, which is essential for muscle contraction. It is indeed present in cardiac muscle cells and has a significant role in the regulation of contraction and relaxation cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are widely distributed throughout the cytoplasm of cells,

 

  1. Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles 
  2. The enzymes within lysosomes are responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials, such as proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and even organelles.
  3. Lysosomes play a crucial role in cellular homeostasis by recycling and eliminating unwanted or damaged cellular components through a process known as autophagy.
  4. The acidic environment within lysosomes (pH around 4.5-5) is necessary for the optimal activity of the digestive enzymes.

 

Lysosomal storage disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher's disease, occur when there is a malfunction or deficiency of enzymes within lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of undigested materials and subsequent cellular dysfunction.

questions.text: Match each disease with the correct causative agent from the options provided: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

 

The correct matching is:

 

  • Donovanosis - Klebsiella granulomatis (A-2)
  • Oroya fever - Bartonella bacilliformis (B-3)
  • Rat bite fever - Streptobacillus moniliformis (C-4)
  • Pinta - Treponema carateum (D-1)

 

For each disease:

 

  1. Donovanosis is a sexually transmitted infection that causes ulcerative lesions, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  2. Oroya fever, also known as Carrion's disease, is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis and is transmitted by sandflies.
  3. Rat bite fever is an infection caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis, typically transmitted through rat bites or contact with rat excreta.
  4. Pinta is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema carateum, characterized by skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The specific causative organisms for these bacterial diseases:

 

  • Donovanosis → Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Oroya fever → Bartonella bacilliformis
  • Rat bite fever → Streptobacillus moniliformis
  • Pinta → Treponema carateum

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.

questions.text: A laboratory technician is analyzing cell populations using flow cytometry. This technique allows for the simultaneous multiparametric analysis of the physical and/or chemical characteristics of single cells flowing through an optical and/or electronic detection apparatus. Which visual depictions are commonly generated in flow cytometry for the evaluation of these cell populations? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Histogram, dot plot

 

  • Histogram and Dot plot can be used to depict flow cytometry analysis.
  • Histogram can be used to compare single parameter (1D)

 

 

 Scatter/Dot plot are used to compare 2 or 3 parameters (2D; 3D)

 

 

Flow Cytometry is used to detect and measure physical and chemical characteristics of a population of cells or parameters like cell counting, sorting, detect microorganisms, detect neoplasm and various more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In flow cytometry, histograms and dot plots are the common visual depictions for evaluating cell populations.

questions.text: During a telemedicine session with patients in a rural health clinic, Dr. Reddy emphasized preventive measures for COVID-19. He highlighted certain practices that are widely recommended. Which of the following, however, is NOT effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1% glutaraldehyde

 

  • A 1% glutaraldehyde solution does not prove effective in preventing the transmission of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face Mask: Wearing face masks significantly helps reduce the transmission of COVID-19 by blocking respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. 70% Alcohol: Alcoholic solutions, particularly those containing at least 60-70% alcohol, are effective in killing viruses on surfaces and are recommended for hand sanitation to reduce viral transmission.

 

Option D. Hand Washing: Regular and thorough hand washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is one of the most effective ways to remove viruses and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key measures that effectively curb its spread include behaviors such as maintaining a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others, washing hands with soap and water for a duration of 20 seconds, or employing a hand sanitizer containing a minimum of 70% alcohol.
  • Additionally, wearing a face mask in situations necessitating public outings remains crucial.

questions.text: Ceftriaxone 180 mg is required for a patient. You're using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml. Ceftriaxone 500 mg/5ml is contained in the vial. How many divisions will you fill in the 2 mL syringe to give 180 mg ceftriaxone? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 18

 

In a vial of Ceftriaxone, it is given than 500mg is there in 5ml.

 

Therefore 180 mg will be present in 1.8 ml.

 

In the 2ml syringe there are 10 divisions per ml.

 

Thus, to take 1.8ml, we need to fill 10*1.8 = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:


To administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Co-trimoxazole only

 

In a patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm presenting with symptoms such as cough and fever, but with a normal chest x-ray, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a likely diagnosis. PCP is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, especially when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/cu.mm.

 

The treatment of choice for PCP is co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). It is essential to start treatment empirically in suspected cases of PCP because delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The dose of co-trimoxazole is typically higher for treating PCP than for prophylaxis.

 

Steroids are indicated in severe cases of PCP to reduce inflammation, specifically if the patient has hypoxemia (PaO2 < 70 mmHg) or an alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient > 35 mmHg. In this scenario, there is no data indicating severe disease, so co-trimoxazole alone is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin: This combination is used for bacterial pneumonia, not PCP. Given the normal chest x-ray and the patient's clinical presentation, bacterial pneumonia is less likely.

 

Option B. Co-trimoxazole + steroids: Steroids are added in severe cases of PCP. However, there is no evidence in this case of severe hypoxemia or an increased A-a gradient to justify the use of steroids along with co-trimoxazole.

 

Option D. Antitubercular treatment: There is no indication from the clinical presentation or the normal chest x-ray that the patient has tuberculosis. Antitubercular treatment is therefore not appropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/cu.mm and presenting with cough and fever but a normal chest x-ray, co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for suspected PCP

 

Note - For a patient with a CD4 count of 200 and lower respiratory tract symptoms:

 

  • PCP Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray is normal or negative.
  • Bacterial Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray shows consolidation or examination reveals bronchial breath sounds.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that typically results from bacteria, most commonly staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, warmth, and redness over the affected area.
  • The infection often leads to chronic discharge from a sinus tract or wound, and systemic symptoms may be less pronounced compared to acute infections.
  • On radiographs or MRI, chronic osteomyelitis may present as:
    • Bone Destruction: There can be areas of bone destruction or loss with possible formation of sequestra (dead bone) and involucrum (new bone formation surrounding the dead bone).
    • Sinus Tracts: Imaging may show draining sinus tracts or soft tissue swelling.
    • Cortical Erosion: There might be cortical erosion or irregularity.

 

 

  • Histopathology: Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by the presence of chronic inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and sometimes necrotic bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing’s Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically found in children and young adults. It is one of the small round blue cell tumors. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and possibly systemic symptoms like fever. The tumor often affects long bones or the pelvis.  On radiographs or MRI, Ewing’s sarcoma can present as a permeative lesion with ill-defined margins, an onion skin periosteal reaction. It is typically associated with an extensive soft tissue mass, an osteolytic lesion with or without calcifications. Histopathologically, it is characterized by small round blue cells with a characteristic "small round cell" appearance and is often confirmed with immunohistochemical staining and cytogenetic analysis (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and occasionally a palpable mass. It is commonly located around the knee or the metaphysis of long bones. On radiographs or MRI, osteosarcoma may present as mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic (sclerotic) lesions, formation of new bone perpendicular to the cortex due to the aggressive nature of the tumor lifting the periosteum, called as Codman’s triangle, and a soft tissue mass. Histopathologically, it shows pleomorphic osteoblasts producing malignant osteoid or bone matrix. Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histological examination.

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Acute Osteomyelitis: Acute Osteomyelitis is a recent infection of the bone, usually caused by bacteria. Symptoms include rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth over the affected area, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. On radiographs or MRI, acute osteomyelitis may not show significant bone changes initially, but can later show bone marrow edema and possible periosteal reaction. As the condition progresses, there may be evidence of bone destruction, sequestra formation, or an abscess. Histopathologically, it is typically characterized by acute inflammatory changes with neutrophils and potentially abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL more than 100 mg/dl

 

Syndrome Z also known as Metabolic Syndrome, is characterized by a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Syndrome involve the pressence of any three of the following five traits: 

 

Any 3/5 for diagnosis:

 

  1. Central Obesity: > 102cm (M),> 88 cm (F); [90(M), 80 cm (F) in Indians]: Only if questions specifically mention Indian population.
  2. BP > 130/85 mmHg
  3. FBS > 100 mg/dL/A1c
  4. Low HDL (in mg/dL): < 40 (F), < 50 cm(M)
  5. High TGL: > 150 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

While LDL cholesterol management is crucial in cardiovascular risk reduction, it is not one of the criteria for diagnosing Metabolic Syndrome, which focuses on abdominal obesity, blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastro/Fatty liver/Chap408

choices.text: Decrease in Vmax
Decrease in Km
Decrease in both Km and Vmax
No change in Vmax

questions.text: Diamox is given to a patient with glaucoma. It is a non-competitive inhibitor of the carbonic anhydrase enzyme. Which of the following would be the effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decrease in Vmax

 

Diamox (acetazolamide) is a non-competitive inhibitor of the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. The effects of a non-competitive inhibitor on enzyme kinetics are distinct:

 

  • Non-competitive Inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site. This binding can occur whether or not the substrate has bound to the enzyme.
  • Vmax Decrease: The non-competitive inhibitor reduces the maximum rate of the reaction (Vmax) because it affects the enzyme's catalytic function. This means that even with a high substrate concentration, the enzyme cannot achieve the same Vmax as it would without the inhibitor.
  • Km Unchanged: The affinity of the enzyme for the substrate, represented by Km, remains unchanged because the inhibitor does not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The substrate can still bind to the enzyme with the same affinity, but the enzyme-inhibitor complex cannot form the product at the same rate as the enzyme alone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease in Km: Explanation: This would be expected in the case of a competitive inhibitor, which increases the substrate concentration needed to achieve half of Vmax, effectively increasing Km. Non-competitive inhibition does not change Km.

 

Option C. Decrease in both Km and Vmax: Explanation: Non-competitive inhibitors do not affect Km because they do not interfere with substrate binding directly. They only reduce the catalytic activity, hence only Vmax is decreased.

 

Option D. No change in Vmax: Explanation: This is incorrect for non-competitive inhibitors, which specifically lower Vmax due to the reduced number of active enzyme molecules available for the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diamox, as a non-competitive inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase, decreases the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction without changing the Michaelis constant (Km). This inhibition reduces the enzyme's catalytic activity but does not alter its substrate binding affinity.

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Incisions

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound (incisions, suction, rubbing, tattooing, vigorous cleaning, massage, application of herbs or chemicals, cryotherapy, cautery) as this may introduce infection, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.

 

First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management. The first aid treatment can be divided in three categories:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Reassurance: Many snake bites are caused by non-venomous snakes. And even after most venomous snake bites, the patient can be saved the risk of death is not immediate. If the patient gets panicked his heart rate would increase which in term would spread the venom rapidly.

 

Option B) Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite: Detailed history will be helpful to know the type of snake Detailed history in snakebite is essential to delineate treatment options moving forward. Information to obtain includes the timing and location of bite, the onset of any symptoms, and any first aid administered in field. Take a past medical history with detail to which medications they are on, especially anti-platelet / anti-coagulant medications, and any allergies that would prohibit from receiving antivenom.

 

Option C) Go to hospital: Main treatment of snake bite can be given in hospital only (Anti-snake venom, airway maintenance, fluids etc.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distal end of ulna

 

Explanation:

 

The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the wrist joint. Instead, it articulates with the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The TFCC acts as a cushion and allows for the smooth rotation of the radius over the ulna during forearm pronation and supination. Due to this articulation with the TFCC and not with the carpal bones, the distal end of the ulna does not form the wrist joint.  .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scaphoid: The scaphoid is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist and is situated on the radial side of the carpus. It articulates proximally with the radius and participates in the formation of the wrist joint.

 

Option B. Triquetrum: The triquetrum is another one of the carpal bones. It is located on the ulnar side of the carpus. Like the scaphoid, the triquetrum also articulates with the distal end of the radius, contributing to the wrist joint's structure.

 

Option C. Distal end of radius: The wrist joint is primarily formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum. Thus, the distal end of the radius plays a crucial role in the formation and function of the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiocarpal joint, also known as the wrist joint, is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint created by the articulation of:

 

  • Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc
  • The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum

 

Just the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius and articular disc when the wrist is in its neutral position; the triquetrum does not come into contact with the disc until the wrist joint is fully adducted.

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capping

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis.

 

Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

 

Note - Capping is done for mRNA (7-methyl guanosine cap) not DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair: DNA methylation is involved in distinguishing parental DNA strands during the mismatch repair process.

 

Option B. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation plays a significant role in the remodeling of chromatin structure.

 

Option D. Gene silencing: DNA methylation is a key mechanism involved in the silencing of genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not related to RNA capping, which is an mRNA modification process. Instead, it is involved in processes such as mismatch repair, chromatin remodeling, and gene silencing.

questions.text:
Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. DiGeorge syndrome
  2. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  3. Ataxia telangiectasia
  4. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Live vaccinations are generally contraindicated in individuals with certain immunodeficiency disorders because their immune systems may not be able to handle the attenuated (weakened) pathogens in the vaccines, potentially leading to severe infections. However, there are exceptions based on the nature of the immunodeficiency.

 

  • Complement deficiency: This is a condition where components of the complement system (a part of the immune system) are deficient. Complement deficiencies do not affect the cellular immune response significantly, meaning that the risk of adverse effects from live vaccinations is not increased. Therefore, individuals with complement deficiency can receive live vaccines safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves a defect in T-cell production due to thymic hypoplasia. Since T-cells are crucial for mounting an immune response to vaccines, live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a condition characterized by defects in both the immune system and DNA repair mechanisms. Patients with this condition have a higher risk of developing severe infections from live vaccines, so they are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting both the immune system and platelet production. Individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome are at risk for severe infections from live vaccines due to their compromised immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.

 

However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: Heller's operation is performed for: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The most common surgical procedure done for achalasia cardia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy in conjugation with partial fundoplication.

 

Heller's operation is most commonly performed to treat Achalasia cardia. Achalasia is a medical condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing and the accumulation of food in the esophagus. Heller myotomy involves cutting the muscles of the LES to alleviate the obstruction and improve the passage of food into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Cancer of the esophagus is typically treated with other approaches such as surgery to remove the tumor, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of these treatments.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: Esophageal stricture refers to the narrowing of the esophagus, often due to scar tissue formation. Treatment for esophageal strictures may involve dilation procedures or other surgical techniques depending on the underlying cause.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Treatment for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically involves a surgical procedure called Ramsteads pyloromyotomy to alleviate the obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia, commonly referred to as achalasia, is a medical condition that affects the esophagus, specifically the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the muscles of the esophageal wall. This condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Failure of LES Relaxation: In achalasia, the LES, a muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the stomach, does not relax properly during swallowing. Normally, the LES should relax to allow food and liquids to pass into the stomach, but in achalasia, this relaxation is impaired.
  2. Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus: Due to the dysfunctional LES, the esophagus is unable to empty food and liquids into the stomach efficiently. This leads to a gradual buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, causing symptoms.
  3. Difficulty in Swallowing: The most prominent symptom of achalasia is dysphagia, which is difficulty in swallowing. Patients often experience a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest while eating and may need to drink fluids or change their body position to help food pass into the stomach.
  4. Regurgitation: As a result of the esophageal emptying problems, patients with achalasia may also experience regurgitation of undigested food, often occurring at night when lying down.
  5. Chest Pain: Some individuals with achalasia may experience chest pain or discomfort, often due to the accumulation of food and fluids in the esophagus.

 

Achalasia is typically diagnosed through tests such as esophageal manometry, which measures the pressure within the esophagus, and barium swallow studies, which show the narrowing of the esophagus and the delayed emptying of contrast material.

 

Treatment options for achalasia include:

 

  • Heller Myotomy: This surgical procedure involves cutting the muscles of the LES to allow for improved passage of food and liquids into the stomach. It is the primary surgical treatment for achalasia.
  • Pneumatic Dilation: In this non-surgical procedure, a balloon is inflated within the LES to stretch and disrupt the muscle fibers, making it easier for food to pass.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection: Injecting botulinum toxin directly into the LES can help relax the muscle temporarily. However, this treatment may need to be repeated periodically.

 

The choice of treatment depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the severity of the condition. Effective management of achalasia can alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for individuals with this disorder.
